name: 2-(trifluoromethoxy)benzoic acid
Reason: The basic unit for the target compound is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The trifluoromethoxy group is an electron-withdrawing group that is highly electronegative due to the presence of fluorine atoms, which can increase the melting point. A trifluoromethoxy group typically raises the melting point by about +40°C due to stronger intermolecular forces (dipole-dipole interactions) and the rigid structure. The carboxylic acid group also has a substantial effect on the melting point because it can form strong hydrogen bonds with other molecules; this can add around +100°C to the melting point. Therefore, combining the effects of the trifluoromethoxy and carboxylic acid groups, we predict an increase in the melting point from the base value of benzene.
